headline: Bitcoin And Crypto De Minimis Tax Exemption Backed By Trump, Says White House
summary: The White House on Thursday confirmed that Presidentâ€¯Donaldâ€¯Trump remains committed to carving out a deâ€¯minimis tax safeâ€‘harbor for everyday Bitcoin and other cryptocurrency payments, a policy his economic team believes will let digital money function â€œas simply as buying a cup of coffee.â€ Trump Backs Bitcoin And Crypto Tax Exemption Press Secretary Karolineâ€¯Leavitt made the remarks during the daily briefing after Bitcoinâ€¯Magazine correspondent Frankâ€¯Corva pressed the administration on whether the president still stands behind the $600 threshold he first floated earlier this year. â€œThe president did signal his support for a deâ€¯minimis exemption for crypto, and the administration continues to be in support of that,â€ Leavitt said, adding that the Treasury and Congress are â€œexploring legislative solutions to accomplish that.â€ Leavitt argued the measure would remove the microâ€‘accounting burden that currently forces users to calculate capitalâ€‘gains tax every time they spend appreciated digital assets. â€œRight now that cannot happen, but with a deâ€¯minimis exemption perhaps it could in the future,â€ she told reporters, framing the carveâ€‘out as critical to Trumpâ€™s pledge to make the Unitedâ€¯States â€œthe crypto capital of the world.â€ The exemption is expected to surface in followâ€‘on tax legislation later this year, but it already has momentum on Capitolâ€¯Hill. The House on Wednesday advanced the bipartisan Genius Act , the first comprehensive federal framework for stablecoins, and a separate bill that would write a deâ€¯minimis standard directly into the Internal Revenue Code. The Genius Act cleared the chamber 308â€‘122 and is scheduled for a Rose Garden signing ceremony on Friday, Leavitt said. Trumpâ€™s push picks up a debate that began in 2022, when senators Patâ€¯Toomey and Kyrstenâ€¯Sinema introduced the Virtual Currency Tax Fairness Act to exempt gains of up to $200 per transactionâ€”far below the $600 ceiling now backed by the White House. Industry groups such as Coinâ€¯Center and the Blockchain Association have long argued that parity with foreignâ€‘currency rules is essential for retail crypto adoption. Leavitt also reiterated that the president â€œopposes a centralâ€‘bank digital currency,â€ noting Trumpâ€™s January executive order barring the Federal Reserve from issuing one and endorsing congressional efforts to codify that ban. She portrayed the combined packageâ€”stablecoin oversight, securitiesâ€‘clarity rules, an antiâ€‘CBDC statute and the forthcoming deâ€¯minimis fixâ€”as â€œa regulatory foundation that will unleash American leadership in digital assets for decades.â€ A $600 exclusion would dramatically reduce friction for lowâ€‘value crypto spending while leaving large transfers fully taxable, striking a balance between usability and revenue protection. Whether the final threshold lands at $200, $600 or is indexed for inflation will hinge on Senate negotiations later this summer, but the White House endorsement gives the measure its strongest tailâ€‘wind yet. As Leavitt summed up: â€œThe president looks forward to signing every piece of proâ€‘crypto legislation Congress can send him.â€ At press time, Bitcoin traded at $120,576.

To understand the recent price action, itâ€™s essential to grasp the concept of â€˜short sellingâ€™ in the crypto market. When traders â€˜shortâ€™ an asset like Ethereum, they are essentially betting its price will fall. They borrow ETH, sell it at the current market price, and hope to buy it back at a lower price later to return it to the lender, profiting from the difference. However, if the price moves against their bet and starts to rise significantly, these short positions can face â€˜liquidation.â€™ This happens when the value of the borrowed asset increases to a point where the short sellerâ€™s collateral is no longer sufficient to cover potential losses. Automated systems then force-close these positions, buying back the ETH to cover the loan. This forced buying creates intense upward pressure, often leading to a rapid price increase known as a â€˜short squeeze.â€™ The recent liquidation of over $136 million in Ethereum shorts acted as a powerful catalyst, propelling ETHâ€™s value higher.
